awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ASSIST - Strengthening Engineering Faculty through Diversity Serving Professional Organization Engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project has a goal of increasing the diversity of engineering faculty at post-secondary institutions through engaging graduate students, post-doctoral professionals and early career faculty in faculty oriented professional development activities.  The lack of diversity in the engineering ranks is well documented.  According to data collected by the American Society for Engineering Education, the percentage of Hispanic tenure track faculty actually declined from 2012 to 2013, from 3.9% to 3.6%.  During that same period, the number of African American faculty also declined from 2.7% to 2.6%. The numbers of American Indian and Hawaiian/Pacific Islanders changed by single digit numbers, their overall percentage being so small that it did not vary significantly.  When considering gender, the number of tenure track female faculty was 14.5% in 2012, a number that has slowly increased from the 8.9% in 2001. It is a national imperative to diversify the engineering profession, and the presence of role models within the engineering faculty ranks is crucial to support the encouragement of underrepresented students seeking and earning engineering degrees. More specifically, 408 engineering doctoral degrees were awarded to members of this target demographic in 2012, however the number of assistant professors only increased by 28 (from 411 to 439). This is FTE for the given year and does not account for faculty that may have been promoted from assistant to associate or those who may have left the academy. If even ¼ of those earning doctorates had joined engineering faculties, this would result in an almost 25% increase in the representation. Clearly greater effort is needed to increase the number of those that earn doctoral degree who choose to enter academic ranks.

Seven engineering professional organizations that target underrepresented populations in engineering and other STEM fields will collaborate on this project: the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES), Great Minds in STEM (GMiS), Latinos in Science and Engineering (MAES), the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), the Society for Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in STEM (SACNAS), the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE), and the Society of Women Engineers (SWE). This project will facilitate travel for graduate students, postdoctoral professionals and early career faculty to attend national engineering conferences hosted by each organization.  Utilizing content experts, these organizations will provide professional development opportunities at these conferences designed to prepare participants to become successful engineering faculty.  By creating a collaborative infrastructure between these organizations, they will design, implement and evaluate the efficacy of increasing engineering faculty diversity through these workshops and professional development activities for the targeted participants.  This activity will also create a self-supporting community engaged in higher educational pursuits thus addressing the isolation often perceived as contributing to the low numbers of faculty from diverse groups. A secondary benefit is that the undergraduate and pre-college students who attend these same conferences will have the opportunity to interact with the graduate students, postdoctoral professionals and early career faculty participants, thereby increasing their opportunity to learn about and potentially seek graduate degrees, increasing the pool of those who seek tenure track positions.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the ASSIST project has been to engage early-career faculty, post-docs, and graduate students with their diversity-serving professional organizations in order to increase the diversity of their informal professional networks. The paucity of diverse faculty in engineering is a well-known problem. In 2013, the National Academy of Engineering convened 70 engineering faculty and staff to discuss the barriers to diversity in engineering (NAE, 2014).The pre-workshop survey identified the ?lack of diversity among faculty themselves? as a key barrier to strengthening institutional receptivity to diversity. Research shows that the lack of strong professional networks is a barrier to success in academic positions. Hitchcock et al. (1995) states, ?successful faculty? -- those who get promoted and tenured, who get recognized for contributions, who produce more and significant research ? consult frequently with colleagues.? His research further indicates that the most important source for developing collegial relationships is professional organizations. Xu and Martin?s research found that limited access to informal professional networks ?contributes to multiple disadvantages including restricted access to critical information, subjection to stereotyping in performance evaluation, fewer opportunities for advancement, and less social, professional, and administrative support.?

Many engineering faculty use their diversity-serving organization chapters to support their persistence and success throughout their education. The ASSIST project was designed to create a mechanism for them to utilize the same means to support their success in the professoriate. Seven engineering diversity societies collaborated on the project:

  • Great Minds in STEM (GMiS) Lead organization
  • American Indian Society of Engineering and Science (AISES)
  • MAES, Latinos in Science and Engineering (MAES)
  • National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE)
  • SACNAS, Advancing Chicanos/Hispanics & Native Americans in Science (SACNAS)
  • Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE)
  • Society of Women Engineers (SWE)

From 2017-2019, the project provided travel grants to early career faculty as a means of encouraging their participation with the additional benefit of encouraging undergraduate students to consider an academic career path.

The specific goals of NSBE ASSIST were to provide African American academics in the early years of their careers with tangible skills and knowledge needed to pursue and gainfully acquire leadership positions at research universities by

  • providing an opportunity for seasoned researchers (university, corporate, government) to nurture connections with their peers and be excited and inspired by the latest discoveries and technical advances across many disciplines of engineering and science.  
  • Creating a space for new collaborations and strategic career advancement.

NSBE partnered with the Academic Research and Leadership Network based at Georgia Tech to offer two days of programming for early career faculty in 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2021. The ARL Symposium has been co-located with the NSBE Annual Conference since 2017.

Broader Impacts

ARLS travel grants were given to students and faculty at over 67 universities from 2017-2019.  This year, participants from 45 universities, 24 of which had not participated before, attended virtual ARLS, making a total of 90 university participants from states across the U.S. over the four-year grant. Since 2017, attendees have represented a total of 24 engineering disciplines. In the ASSIST proposal, NSBE agreed to recruit 40 early career faculty per year for this professional development experience, or a total of 160 participants. NSBE ASSIST exceeded this goal for a total of 193 early career faculty and postdoc participants over the four years of the grant. This is more than a strong start toward achieving broader impacts and moving the needle on increasing the diversity of engineering faculty nationwide.

Intellectual Merit

Because of the data collected through the ASSIST portal, ASSIST has contributed to understanding the demographics of underrepresented minorities and women aspiring to and pursuing careers in engineering. It has contributed professional development and strengthened professional networking opportunities to support the career success and the personal well-being of African American participants. It has also helped participants develop greater understanding of the role of research in academic careers and provided strategies for securing research funding.

In every year of the NSBE ASSIST project, early career faculty and post-graduate students have rated the development of networking relationships as the most valuable part of their experience at ARLS, thus achieving a primary project goal.  The establishment of these networks is critical for the success and retention of academically talented

Not only that, this year for the first time, NSBE ASSIST collected longitudinal data from 35 participants on their academic achievements since 2019. The data shows that African American early career faculty in engineering are achieving promotions, tenure, fellowships, grants, endowed chairs, and other forms of recognition. Through the development of resources for graduate students, post-docs and untenured faculty, NSBE is building a body of knowledge to support Black engineers who are seeking careers in academia.
